abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely, though institutional development
            impacts are modest, based on difficulties to retain workers
            with acquired skills, given the high levels of staff
            rotation. Among the lessons learned, it is reinforced that
            stakeholders ownership is crucial for successful outcomes,
            as is an effective steering committee in coordinating the
            multiple interventions of capacity building within a
            project. However, training should be a permanent, ongoing
            activity for capacity building to succeed, particularly in
            an environment of frequent staff transfers. Moreover,
            consideration should be given to the sustainability of
            institutional development projects, who are substantially
            dependent on the availability of budgetary funds to meet
            recurrent costs; likewise, the costly undertaking of small
            technical assistance projects - compared with total
            disbursements - should raise overall investments questions.
            Lessons also convey that the implementation delays as of the
            early start of the project, could have been avoided, had
            conditions of effectiveness been minimal.

18153527.theme: Public expenditure, financial management and procurement,Administrative and civil service reform
18153527.trustfund: UN007140-ASSES.OF THE SOCIAL COSTS OF STRUCT.ADJ.,TF020090-BELGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF027965-ECONOMIC MANAGEMENT PROJECT IN BENIN,TF020940-NORWAY-SDA ASESMNT OF SOCIAL DIMENSIONS

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is designed to improve
            economic management capabilities in Benin.  In particular
            the project aims at:  (i) strengthening the preparation and
            management of the Public Investment Program (PIP), the
            Budget, and improving the quality of the National Accounts;
            (ii) strengthening staff capabilities in economic and
            financial management, and establishing a permanent
            government capability to train its own staff; and (iii)
            supporting the government's overall economic reform
            program.  To achieve these objectives, the project will:
            (i) provide support for the development of a training
            program to be carried out in a national training center; and
            (ii) provide support to the preparation and execution of the
            PIP and the budget through technical assistance to the
            Ministry of Planning, the Ministry of Finance and the
            sectoral ministries.  The project will also finance studies
            and consultant services to support the implementation of the
            government's economic reform program.
